title: 'Fire Begets More Fires': Rainforests Slip Into Cycle of Destruction
summary: Research shows the very nature of rainforests is changing as a result of clearing. As large tracts of Indonesia's forest land go up in flames for the second time in five years, scientists are warning that the world's rainforests risk becoming caught in a reinforcing cycle of destruction that could make them difficult to save.

title: U.S. to Try Diplomacy in Turkey as Russian Forces Swoop In
summary: President Trump's withdrawal of American troops created an opening for Moscow to expand its clout; Pence and Pompeo to meet with Erdogan in a bid to stem hostilities against Kurds. The Trump administration dispatched senior officials to Turkey to press for an end to Ankara's military offensive in northeastern Syria, as Moscow began to fill a void created by departing U.S. troops.

title: Pence, Giuliani Say They Won't Give Up Documents in Impeachment Probe
summary: Defying GOP, Speaker Pelosi won't hold vote authorizing probe. WASHINGTON-The office of Vice President Mike Pence declined to comply with a records request from House committees leading an impeachment inquiry into President Trump, while Rudy Giuliani, Mr. Trump's personal lawyer, said he doesn't intend to comply with a congressional subpoena for documents.

title: U.S. House Passes Bills Supporting Hong Kong Protesters
summary: Lawmakers approve sanctioning Chinese officials found to suppress freedoms in the city; Trump has taken cautious approach on demonstrations. WASHINGTON-The House of Representatives unanimously passed a series of bills supporting protesters in Hong Kong who have called for democratic reforms in the city, delivering a rebuke to Beijing for what the U.S. lawmakers called a corrosion of individual freedoms in the territory.

title: Trump Vetoes Second Attempt to End Emergency Declaration
summary: President says situation at southern border remains a national emergency. President Trump vetoed a second Congressional attempt to terminate his February national emergency declaration, which directed money from other projects to pay for a wall on the U.S.-Mexico border.

title: State Department Official Testifies in Impeachment Probe
summary: Kent had raised concerns about efforts by Rudy Giuliani and others to undercut former U.S. ambassador to Ukraine. House committees on Tuesday questioned Deputy Assistant Secretary of State George Kent, the most senior-ranking current member of the Trump administration to give testimony in the impeachment inquiry centered on Ukraine.

title: Bolton, Mulvaney on Opposite Sides of Pivotal Ukraine Debate
summary: Two key Trump advisers pursued different strategies on the issue now at heart of House's impeachment inquiry. WASHINGTON-During President Trump's tenure in office, both his chief of staff and his national security adviser have listened to most scheduled calls with foreign leaders, according to current and former White House officials. During the phone conversation this summer that sparked an impeachment inquiry, neither of the two key advisers was on the line.

title: In College-Admissions Case, Lawyers for Coaches, Others Move to Dismiss Charges
summary: Court filings challenge the structure of the conspiracy indictment, accuse the government of casting too wide a net. BOSTON-Lawyers representing former coaches from prominent college athletic programs filed motions in federal court Tuesday seeking to dismiss the charges against them in the nationwide college-admissions case, arguing the case inappropriately lumped together individuals who weren't conspiring to commit crimes with one another.

title: Astros Take 2-1 Series Lead After a Masterful Outing by Gerrit Cole
summary: Cole threw seven scoreless innings in Game 3 of the ALCS; Rain could push Game 4 to Thursday. NEW YORK-Gerrit Cole isn't the most famous pitcher in this postseason. At 29 years old, he's not even the most accomplished pitcher on his own team. But he is dominating hitters like no other pitcher in these playoffs, and the Houston Astros are two wins from the World Series because of it.

title: Berkshire Asks to Expand BofA Stake
summary: Application to the Fed underscores Warren Buffett's positive outlook on the lender and on the U.S. banking sector. Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway Inc. requested permission earlier this month from the Federal Reserve to increase its stake in Bank of America Corp. above 10%.

title: Multiple Earthquakes Shake California
summary: U.S. Geological Survey warns of aftershocks after 4.5-magnitude quake in the San Francisco Bay Area. A 4.5-magnitude earthquake struck the eastern part of the San Francisco Bay Area on Monday night, jolting residents as far south as San Jose.

title: U.S. Troop Withdrawal Upends Syria Policy, Leaving a Search for Solutions
summary: American policy makers scramble to maintain clout and contain Russia, Iran. WASHINGTON-President Trump's decision to quickly remove American forces from northern Syria has upended years of U.S. strategy, leaving policy makers looking for ways to maintain clout and contain Russian and Iranian influence in a strategically important region.

title: Health-Care Stocks Get a Welcome Respite
summary: Sector has been among worst-performing in S&P 500 this year, climbing just 5.7%. Health-care stocks rallied Tuesday as strong earnings reports from UnitedHealth Group Inc. and Johnson & Johnson provided a much-needed shot of optimism for the sector.

title: J.B. Hunt Third-Quarter Profit Falls Short of Expectations
summary: Freight operator reports flat volumes in key intermodal segment, rising rail transport costs. J.B. Hunt Transport Services Inc. reported roughly flat load volumes in its truck-rail intermodal business in the latest period, which still drove a better-than-expected 7% increase in overall revenue.

title: Child Hot-Car Deaths Are Near Record High This Year
summary: Vehicular heat stroke has been the cause of death for 49 children so far in 2019, National Safety Council says. The number of children who have died from heatstroke this year after being left or getting trapped in hot cars is among the highest on record.

title: América Móvil Reports 31% Drop in Net Profit on Forex Losses
summary: The currency losses offset gains in sales and operating profits for Latin America's biggest wireless operator. MEXICO CITY-Mexican telecommunications company América Móvil SAB reported a 31% decline in third-quarter net profit as foreign-exchange losses in the period partly offset gains in sales and operating profits.

title: MGM Resorts to Sell Bellagio, Circus Circus Properties in Las Vegas
summary: Bellagio will be put into joint venture controlled by Blackstone; MGM will continue to operate the hotel and casino. LAS VEGAS- MGM Resorts International said it is selling two casinos on the Las Vegas Strip, including its landmark Bellagio property, in separate real-estate deals.

title: Warren and Sanders, Policy Mates
summary: Their differences are mainly about rhetorical labeling.. Bernie Sanders wants voters to know that he-not Elizabeth Warren-is the bona fide socialist running for President in 2020. "There are differences between Elizabeth and myself," Mr. Sanders said Sunday on ABC. "Elizabeth I think, as you know, has said that she is a capitalist through her bones. I'm not."

title: The Tariff Redistribution Act
summary: Turning border taxes into another form of political largesse.. President Trump's tariffs have cost American consumers billions of dollars, via higher prices on everything from washing machines to beer kegs. Mr. Trump tacitly admitted this in August when he said he delayed more border taxes on Chinese goods for the sake of "the Christmas shopping season."

title: LeBron's Hong Kong Education
summary: The NBA star agrees with Donald Trump on something.. Holding up sports stars as moral arbiters is usually a mistake, as the case of basketball star LeBron James and Hong Kong demonstrates. The man who lectures America on its many sins went soft this week on the People's Republic of China.

title: Mozambique Fraud Trial Begins as Voters Go to the Polls
summary: U.S. begins its case against alleged mastermind of $2 billion fraud on election day in southern African nation. The trial against one of the alleged ringleaders behind $2 billion in fraudulent loans to Mozambique kicked off in New York on Tuesday, the same day citizens of the southern African nation cast judgment at the ballot box on whether their government had done enough to hold to account officials involved in the secret deals.

title: Drug Distributors Are in Talks to Pay $18 Billion to Settle Opioid Litigation
summary: McKesson, AmerisourceBergen, Cardinal Health discussing settlements with state, local governments. Three major drug distributors are in talks to pay $18 billion to settle sweeping litigation brought by state and local governments blaming them for fueling the opioid crisis, people familiar with the discussions said, paving the way for a broad resolution to lawsuits that have shaken the pharmaceutical industry.

title: 'Narrative Economics' Review: Costly Tales We Tell Ourselves
summary: Like songs you can't get out of your head, familiar story lines about the economy elicit thoughts and emotions; they also impel action.. Economics is the study of people at work, but where are the people? Many a learned economist forgets all about them. Not Robert Shiller, the author of "Narrative Economics," who believes that volatile human emotion counts for more than you think in the ostensibly objective valuation of stocks, bonds and buildings.

title: The Hong Kong Crackdown Has Begun
summary: Beijing hasn't sent tanks into the streets. It's trying to do the job with criminal gangs and technology.. Hong Kong

title: When China Won't Play Ball
summary: Students grade the NBA's response to Beijing's bullying.. Editor's note: This Future View is about China's spat with the National Basketball Association and the league's response. Students should click here to submit opinions of fewer than 250 words before Oct. 22. The best responses will be published that night.

title: The UAW's Long Endgame
summary: No, management and stockholders are not 'grateful' for the union's sacrifices.. The United Auto Workers union is a real thing. It's not a trope. It is not an abstraction on which to operate the principle that in political discussion, all words devolve into synonyms for good and bad (to many in the press, labor is good and management is bad).

title: Turkey's Halkbank Charged in Iran Sanctions Evasion Case
summary: Criminal prosecution adds to U.S. pressure on Erdogan amid Syria offensive. Federal prosecutors in Manhattan charged Turkish state-owned lender Halkbank with a multibillion-dollar scheme to evade U.S. sanctions on Iran, ramping up pressure on Turkey's President Recep Tayyip Erdogan as he conducts a military offensive on Syria.

title: Trump Speaks Loudly, Carries a Toothpick
summary: Betraying the Kurds harms U.S. allies and interests. It's already made Israel nervous.. Game, set and match to Vladimir Putin in Syria. President Trump's hasty and ill-advised withdrawal of American tripwire forces from Syria has forced the Kurds into a deal with dictator Bashar Assad, whose forces are re-entering the country's Northeast region. With a modest investment, the Russian president not only staved off defeat for Mr. Assad but has moved close to his goal of reunifying Syria under his client's control.

title: California and New York Show the Ugly Face of 'Progress'
summary: Voters may not like Trump, but they can see what the Democrats' ideas look like when put into action.. Don't be fooled by the dozen people on stage for Tuesday's Democratic presidential debate. For now, this is a two-person contest between Joe Biden and Elizabeth Warren, who have distanced themselves from the rest of the pack in national polls and in the early-voting states.

title: We Sent a Man to the Moon. We Can Send the Dollar to Cyberspace
summary: Washington should edge out rivals with a regulated platform for trading greenbacks via blockchain.. America was complacent about its technological dominance until the Soviets' 1957 Sputnik launch woke us up. Recent developments in digital currencies similarly threaten the dollar's dominance, and Washington policy makers are taking notice.

summary: Carnegie Hall's lights finally shine on Gina Drangel.. New York

title: Few Selective New York City Schools Post Precise Admissions Criteria
summary: Just 20 of 157 screened high-school programs put their rubrics for evaluating applicants online, or gave them to researchers upon request, a report said. Selective New York City public high schools are supposed to make it easy for families to see their detailed admission criteria, but only a fraction of schools do so, according to a new report from Fordham Law School.

summary: She wants more data before finalizing her monetary-policy views. San Francisco Fed leader Mary Daly said that while central-bank rate cuts will help keep the economy on a good path, she isn't ready to say whether another rate change is warranted.

title: GM, UAW Move Closer to Agreement That Would End Strike
summary: CEO Mary Barra meets with union leadership in effort to solidify agreement. General Motors Co. and the United Auto Workers are nearing a contract deal to end a 30-day strike at the company's factories, with bargainers moving closer on earlier sticking points and leaders from each side engaging in high-level talks.

summary: Separatist supporters take to streets to protest jail sentences meted out over 2017 independence referendum. BARCELONA-Thousands of pro-independence protesters took to the streets of Catalonia, in a second day of tumult over the jail sentences given by Spain's highest court to nine Catalan separatists for their role in the region's illegal independence referendum in 2017.

title: FirstEnergy Solutions' Restructuring Plan Gets Bankruptcy Court Approval
summary: FES wins judge's backing after making concessions to union workers. The judge presiding over FirstEnergy Solutions Corp.'s bankruptcy said he would approve the power producer's restructuring terms, helping to clear the way for the Ohio company to wrap up the chapter 11 by year-end.

summary: A preliminary pact could be reached by Wednesday morning, people close to the talks say, but talks could still stall. title: Brexit Hopes Carry Pound and Banking Stocks Higher
summary: U.K. and EU are reportedly close to nearing a draft agreement. The British pound and stocks of banks and home builders rallied Tuesday on speculation that the U.K. and European Union might be close to finishing a draft divorce agreement.

title: This Dallas Apartment Building's Sole Tenant Is a New Lodging Company
summary: Wall Street analysts are pointing to such firms as a reason why hotel room rates have been falling in major cities. An apartment-hotel company that manages short-term rentals is leasing and managing an entire 26-story Dallas apartment building, the latest sign this budding segment of the lodging market is starting to gain traction.

summary: Jake Menges was chief lobbyist for New York City when Rudy Giuliani was mayor. Jake Menges, a longtime aide to Rudy Giuliani, said he has stepped down from the law firm Greenberg Traurig to lead a Florida-focused super PAC backing President Trump.

title: Dollar's Stability Continues to Hurt Commodities
summary: U.S. currency remains near multiyear peak despite projections for the economy to slow. Gold, oil prices tick down.. The U.S. dollar remains near a multiyear peak despite projections for the domestic economy to slow in the months ahead, a continuing challenge for bullish commodity investors as the currency keeps contributing to lower materials prices.

title: Johnson & Johnson Raises Outlook, Beats Profit Estimates
summary: Sales in pharmaceuticals division grew by about 5% to $10.88 billion in latest quarter. Johnson & Johnson raised its financial forecast for the rest of 2019, despite grappling with a heavy case load of litigation, as it reported quarterly results that were above Wall Street estimates, boosted by gains in its consumer and pharmaceuticals divisions.

title: United Raises Outlook on Robust Demand
summary: Summer travel, lower fuel outstrip effects of MAX grounding at No. 2 U.S. carrier. United Airlines Holdings Inc. reported third-quarter profit that outstripped expectations, and it raised its earnings estimates for the year as a surge in booking demand helped offset the challenges of the grounding of Boeing Co. 's 737 MAX.

summary: Search-engine giant tries to recharge a business segment with a new flagship phone and a cheaper laptop-tablet. Google showed off additions to its line of smartphones, wireless earbuds and other personal electronics in its latest attempt to recharge a business-segment laggard.

title: Treasury Rally, Low Rates Key to Stock Gains: Bill Gross
summary: Onetime 'bond king' sees sign investors should abandon expectations for double-digit returns for stocks. About 15% of the stock market's gains this year are attributable to the rally in U.S. Treasurys, a sign that investors should abandon expectations for double-digit returns for stocks in the future, according to the man once known as Wall Street's "bond king."

title: Supreme Court Appears Likely to Back Puerto Rico Debt-Relief Board
summary: Issue is whether Congress erred in allowing members to serve without Senate confirmation. WASHINGTON-The Supreme Court on Tuesday appeared likely to uphold the special board that Congress created to resolve Puerto Rico's debt crisis, despite claims from creditors that its members were wrongly appointed.

title: Manhattan Traffic 'Fix' Jams Up Some Residents
summary: Vehicles are moving on 14th Street, but locals say congestion has worsened on nearby streets. Opponents of a traffic change to speed up mass transit on one of Manhattan's busiest streets have vowed to fight on despite a broadly positive reception to the initiative.

title: 'Slave Play' Makes Solid Start on Broadway
summary: Producers extend show's limited engagement by another two weeks, through Jan. 19. In many respects, Jeremy Harris's "Slave Play" is a drama that hardly fits Broadway's commercial model.

summary: Though little is known about Greene, who died in 1856 at age 24, his photographs reveal the artist's formal daring and precocity.. San Francisco

title: U.S. Stocks Rise as Earnings Season Kicks Off
summary: UnitedHealth, Johnson & Johnson, JPMorgan open quarter's reporting period on a high note. U.S. stocks climbed Tuesday as investors cheered strong results from banks and health-care companies at the unofficial start of the third-quarter earnings season.

title: Left of Obama
summary: Few of his judges make a "progressive" wish list for the Supreme Court.. This column is not the first to notice that Democratic politicians seem to spend about half the day accusing President Trump of trashing vaguely defined Constitutional norms-and the other half explaining how they plan to trash enumerated Constitutional rights. As for the latter activity, Tuesday night's Democratic presidential debate is another opportunity for candidates to show how much damage they intend to inflict on the first two Amendments. Now prominent activists are demanding that candidates promise to be more radical than America's 44th President.

title: 'The Last Knight: The Art, Armor, and Ambition of Maximilian I' Review: Finding Perfection in Protection
summary: An exhibition explores themes important to Emperor Maximilian's life and career, especially his love of armor as a craft and as a symbol of the knightly valor with which he wished to be identified.. New York

summary: Strong results from UnitedHealth, Johnson & Johnson help investors look past Obamacare and opioid legal issues. One of the stock market's most frail patients suddenly appears to be in excellent shape.

title: Judge Blocks Michigan Ban on Flavored E-Cigarettes
summary: Delay in implementing the ban undercut the governor's position that emergency rules were justified, judge found. LANSING, Mich.-A Michigan judge on Tuesday blocked the state's weeks-old ban on flavored e-cigarettes, citing evidence that adults could return to smoking more harmful tobacco products.

title: Pinterest Shares Slide as Lockup Expires
summary: Stock has fallen nearly 5% this week. Big institutional investors in Pinterest Inc. are now free to unload their shares of the online image-board company, sending the stock down nearly 5% this week.

title: Left Has No Good Answers for U.S. Doctors
summary: When doctors become hired hands of giant corporations, they will worry more about saving dollars than saving lives. Today, the corporate takeover of American medicine is complete.. Which major political party doctors may be aligned with is really immaterial to the arc of health-care policy during the past 50 years ("Changes in Medicine Push Doctors to Left," Page One, Oct. 7). Back in 1986, your reporter quoted me as saying that "when doctors become hired hands of giant corporations, they will worry more about saving dollars than saving lives." Today, the corporate takeover of American medicine is complete.

title: PG&E Blackouts: California as Third World
summary: California, once the innovation leader of the world, and sixth or seventh largest economy in the world, has become a Third World state than cannot even provide reliable electric service to millions of its residents.. "Fire Fears Push PG&E to Black Out Millions" (Page One, Oct. 10) should be a wake-up call for businesses and homeowners. In the last century we have become utterly dependent on reliable ubiquitous electricity. There's the outlet, one plugs in and life goes on. But our national electrical grids are straining to meet the ever-increasing demand for power. And the grids are old, poorly maintained and not designed for fine, selective deactivation. PG&E must turn off power wholesale for millions to avoid causing fires in multiple isolated-risk areas. End users should prepare now to make their own electricity, at least to the extent needed to maintain critical functions such as medical devices. Solar panels and home batteries are one approach. And backup generators are cheap and can run day and night.

title: UnitedHealth Raises Profit Targets on Higher Sales
summary: Results top analyst expectations as net income rises to $3.54 billion in quarter. UnitedHealth Group Inc. boosted its profit guidance for the year as revenue growth from its health services and insurance units fueled the company's third-quarter performance.

title: Ships Can Serve Where U.S. Pipelines Aren't Available
summary: The unreasonable barriers to pipeline expansion to carry liquefied natural gas (LNG) could be mitigated immediately by allowing foreign-flag tankers to transport LNG in domestic trade.. Regarding Paul H. Tice's "Trump Hasn't Solved the Pipeline Crisis" (op-ed, Oct. 9) about unreasonable barriers to pipeline expansion to carry liquefied natural gas (LNG): The problem could be mitigated immediately by allowing foreign-flag tankers to transport LNG in domestic trade. It could be done by exempting LNG trade from the burdensome Jones Act because no Jones Act-compliant tankers exist today. Relaxing restrictions would reduce regional imbalances in the continental U.S. and improve supplies to Hawaii and Puerto Rico, which cannot be served by pipelines. The perverse U.S. shipping policy has resulted in Hawaii, Puerto Rico and other U.S. regions importing propane, when the U.S. is the largest producer and exporter of propane in the world.

title: Past Impeachments Offer Some Clues to the Future
summary: Every time the Republican or Democratic Party tried to impeach a president-or succeeded- but failed to convict him in the U.S. Senate, that party's nominee won the White House in the next election.. In "Polls Argue Against Impeachment" (Politics & Ideas, Oct. 2), William A. Galston says Democrats must ask themselves if impeachment will improve their chance of defeating President Trump in the 2020 election. Every time a party tried to impeach a president-or succeeded-but failed to convict him in the Senate, that party's nominee won the White House in the next election.

title: Strange Bedfellows: Milton Friedman and Andrew Yang
summary: Andrew Yang has yet to reap the benefits from his $1,000 a month to all proposal.. Bobby Jindal's "Trump Wins Every Democratic Debate" (op-ed, Oct. 14) mentions Democratic candidate Andrew Yang, but Mr. Yang has yet to reap the benefits from his $1,000-a-month-to-all proposal. In 1967 I was enrolled in a graduate-level economics course at UCLA taught by Milton Friedman. He proposed a $1,000 monthly negative-income-tax payment to every citizen. There were no strings attached at all. Each person could use the money any way he or she chose. An integral feature of his proposal was to eliminate hundreds of thousands of bureaucratic jobs. There would be no one monitoring how the money was distributed or how people used the money. Waste it and you might be on charity's doorstep.

title: Nevada Regulator Seeks to Ban Steve Wynn From State's Casino Industry
summary: Board urges that former executive's status as a person suitable to hold a casino license be revoked, asserting that his conduct has damaged the state's gambling business. LAS VEGAS-Steve Wynn should be banned from Nevada's casino industry because of his alleged sexual misconduct against former employees, according to a state regulator's filing on Monday.

title: Brookfield Embarks on High-Price Makeover of Fifth Avenue Tower
summary: When work on 666 Fifth Ave. is done, the building will have a new address and substantially higher rents. Real-estate giant Brookfield Asset Management is starting a $400 million overhaul of the tower at 666 Fifth Avenue, undeterred by a lackluster office leasing market in Midtown Manhattan and an aging bull market in commercial property.

title: America's Got Talent, Just Not Enough in IT
summary: Companies sweeten perks to land tech workers; a $250,000 signing bonus for an executive role. title: SmileDirectClub Shares Hit Low After California Bill
summary: Legislation includes language threatening to make it tougher for teeth-straightening startup to sell in the state. title: Is It Creepy to Do Halloween After Your Kids Are Grown?
summary: Columnist Michelle Slatalla searches for holiday décor to signal that she and her husband welcome trick-or-treaters but don't want to lure them indoors to eat them. THE OTHER DAY when we were excavating the terrifying cellar where we store all the things we should have thrown away, my husband opened a musty cardboard box. Inside he found a pile of moldy severed limbs, a human skull and a nest of bloody rats suckling their mother.

title: Google Not Home Yet in Hardware
summary: Unlike Microsoft and Amazon, Google is still seeking the right niche for its devices. Google has long been able to afford to play in hardware like it has nothing to lose. But that enviable position has yet to produce a clear win.

title: Cuba Gooding Jr. Faces New Sex-Crime Charges

summary: Losses on bank's stakes in companies hit quarterly earnings. Goldman Sachs Group Inc.'s third-quarter profit fell 26% from a year ago, hit by a slowdown in deal-making and losses on the bank's stakes in companies.

title: Why Kirsten Dunst Traded Couture for Sweats
summary: The star of Showtime's "On Becoming a God in Central Florida," who's a new mother, may not be in the fashion-plate period of her life any more but she's still in the spotlight. Her profile has steadily risen from her fame-securing "Interview with a Vampire" role, at 12, to a Gap ad, at age 17, turns as Mary Jane in the pre-Marvel multiverse "Spider-Man" films and the title role in "Marie Antoinette." title: LeBron James's Big Miss on China
summary: Given the chance to discuss an international incident, the NBA's biggest star only widens the controversy. LeBron James botched it. There's no use soft-pedaling it, or claiming otherwise. The NBA star has shown himself to be a considerate person, and he and his associates had plenty of time to plan a much better answer to a big question he was inevitably going to get. Dumping on Houston Rockets general manager Daryl Morey's tweet in support of Hong Kong protesters as "misinformed or not really educated on the situation" was a public relations brick for an athlete who's usually far more deft in high-profile situations.

title: TikTok to Review Content-Moderation Policy After Censorship Accusation
summary: Video-sharing platform hires law firm to address topics including child safety, hate speech and misinformation. WASHINGTON-Video-sharing platform TikTok, under fire for allegedly censoring content to appease China, has hired two former U.S. lawmakers as part of a team to review its content-moderation policy, the company said Tuesday.

title: Germany Won't Ban Huawei from 5G Network
summary: Draft of new security requirements paves way for Huawei inclusion in German telecom networks, even as U.S. and EU warn of risks.

title: Citigroup Hits Return Target, Profit Rises
summary: New York bank's third-quarter earnings top expectations; profit climbs 6%. Citigroup Inc. on Tuesday said its third-quarter profit rose 6% and beat expectations.

title: Banks Bounce, but Rates Still Exert Gravitational Pull
summary: Beneath the surface of banks' decent quarter are some troubling trends. Beneath the surface of banks' decent quarter are some troubling trends.

title: Dan Coats, Trump's Former Intelligence Chief, Rejoins Law Firm
summary: Ex-director of national intelligence returns to King & Spalding as a senior policy adviser on national security. WASHINGTON-President Trump's former director of national intelligence has rejoined his law firm after leading the nation's spy agencies through a tumultuous period.

title: Peabody to Close Coal Mine Amid Price Drop
summary: The plan to shut an Illinois mine and processing plant adds to a steady drumbeat of coal operations shutting down due to declining demand. Peabody Energy Corp said Monday it plans to shutter a mine and coal processing facility in Saline County, Ill. due to "uneconomic mining conditions" as U.S. coal producers continue to face depressed pricing and competitive pressure from other energy sources.

title: As Trump Prepares to Choose Another DHS Head, Obstacles Emerge
summary: Cuccinelli and Morgan are top internal candidates, but regulatory concerns cloud paths for each. WASHINGTON-President Trump's expected selection of a successor to acting Homeland Security Secretary Kevin McAleenan this week is likely to provide a new direction for the agency chiefly responsible for carrying out immigration policy, but a pick could also run into legal hurdles.

title: Buffett Critic Has Extra Mustard, Less Bread
summary: Fund manager David Rolfe has a biting critique of Berkshire Hathaway, yet he failed to cash in on the opportunities he criticizes. David Rolfe and the investment firm he helms, Wedgewood Partners, are hardly household names. The Missouri-based firm got plenty of press recently, though, by dissing a far more famous Midwestern investor.

title: JPMorgan Posts Seventh Straight Profit Gain
summary: Shares of the largest U.S. bank rise about 4% after earnings beat analysts' forecast. JPMorgan Chase & Co.'s third-quarter profit rose 8% and topped expectations as the bank continued to see strength in its consumer businesses and a strong investment-bank performance.

title: Amazon Joins Trend of Sending Workers Away for Health Care
summary: Employers pay staffers' expenses to travel to select hospitals and doctors, in bid to control costs. Employers are increasingly going the distance to control health spending, paying to send workers across the country to get medical care and bypassing local health-care providers.

title: Trade Skepticism Further Fuels Investors' Push Into Cash, Treasurys
summary: Survey shows many investors view U.S.-China trade war as biggest risk to the market. Fund managers around the world have crammed into U.S. Treasurys and moved more of their assets into cash in October, more defensive positions as many continued to harbor reservations about the U.S. reaching a trade pact with China.

title: Audit Watchdog Plagued by Internal Strife, Whistleblower Claims
summary: Regulator issues fewer audit-inspection reports as board struggles with infighting and senior staff shortage. A watchdog tasked with protecting investors by policing audits of public companies has slowed its work amid board infighting, multiple senior staff departures, and allegations that the chairman has created a "sense of fear," according to a whistleblower letter and people familiar with the situation.

title: Long-Term Inflation Expectations Hit Record Low: N.Y. Fed
summary: Three-year ahead inflation expectations fell to 2.4% in September. The Federal Reserve Bank of New York said Tuesday that longer-run inflation expectations hit the lowest level the bank has ever tracked in its latest monthly Survey of Consumer Expectations.

title: Musician Clint Black on the Food and Poetry That Nourished His Country Soul
summary: His Sicilian mother taught him how to make her pasta sauce, a school drama class gave him a love of writing. Clint Black, 57, is a Grammy-winning country singer-songwriter with 22 No. 1 Billboard country music hits and 30 albums in the top 10. His new album is "Still Killin' Time" (Blacktop), due out Nov. 8. He spoke with Marc Myers.

title: BlackRock Profit Slips
summary: Money-management firm sees bigger net inflows into cash, bond funds over equity funds. BlackRock Inc.'s profits fell by 8% in the third quarter as the investment giant's assets shifted into less lucrative products.

title: So You Make $100,000? It Still Might Not Be Enough to Buy a Home.
summary: Resume Subscription. DENVER-For Janessa White, the American dream of a red brick house on a tree-lined street blocks from a good elementary school remains obtainable. She just has to rent it.

title: It All Started With a Toy Car
summary: Resume Subscription. Desmond FitzGerald of Fairfield County, Conn., 75, an investor and philanthropist for health care in developing countries, on his 1936 Lagonda LG45, as told to A.J. Baime.

title: Photos: The Lagonda Was Love at First Sight
summary: 'I liked this car instantly,' says Desmond FitzGerald, who first saw a toy one as a child and now owns a 1936 model. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Want to Win That Race? Hire a Coach to Stay Alongside You and Carry Your Phone
summary: Amateurs pay trainers to enter marathons with them; 'like a little concierge service'. Diane Reynolds had been racing for a few months when she won her first amateur cycling event, the Farm to Fork Fondo near upstate New York's Finger Lakes in August. She left more than 500 riders in the dust, including all the men.

title: Elizabeth Warren Limits Donations From Some Bank, Tech Execs
summary: Presidential candidate doubles down on fundraising approach under scrutiny from some fellow Democrats. WASHINGTON-Elizabeth Warren's presidential campaign will no longer accept contributions of more than $200 from executives at certain tech companies or financial firms, her latest move to keep big business at bay.

title: Stocks to Watch: JPMorgan Chase, Citigroup, Wells Fargo, United Health, J&J and More
summary: Here are some of the companies with shares expected to trade actively Tuesday. Here are some of the companies with shares expected to trade actively in Tuesday's session. Stock movements noted by ticker reflect movements during regular trading hours; premarket trading is specified separately.

title: Japan Questions Flooding Defenses After Severe Weekend Typhoon
summary: Dozens of rural communities were hit as rivers overflowed, killing at least 74 and leaving thousands of houses inundated. TOKYO-Japan on Tuesday was questioning its defenses against flooding after a larger-than-expected toll from a weekend typhoon, which caused more than 180 rivers to overflow or break their banks.

title: Fed Adds $87.7 Billion To Financial System in Latest Repo Transactions
summary: Banks asked for $67.6 billion in overnight reserves, all of which the Fed accepted. The Federal Reserve Bank of New York added $87.7 billion to the financial system Tuesday, using the market for repurchase agreements, or repo, to relieve funding pressure in money markets.

title: Global Economy on Course for Weakest Growth Since Crisis
summary: IMF lowers estimate for 2019 to 3% as international trade slows to nearly a standstill. WASHINGTON-The global economy in 2019 is on course for its weakest year of growth since the financial crisis, weighed down by tensions that have slowed international trade to nearly a standstill.

title: Hunter Biden Defends His Ukraine Work
summary: Joe Biden's son says in ABC News interview he 'not in any way whatsoever' acted improperly. The son of former Vice President Joe Biden said he used "poor judgment" when he decided to join the board of a Ukrainian energy company, providing fodder to his father's political adversaries, but said he did nothing improper.

title: 'The O.C.' Creator Josh Schwartz Still Speaks Fluent Teenager
summary: The man who gave us Gossip Girl is back with Nancy Drew and Looking For Alaska, two new shows for the high school crowd he knows so well.. When The O.C. premiered in the summer of 2003, Josh Schwartz's skill at writing teen characters was easy to pin on his own proximity to high school. He was just 26-an unusually young age for a showrunner in Hollywood.

title: Aldi, Lidl Cut Into U.S. Grocers' Turf
summary: Supermarkets are lowering prices, adding products to compete with German discounters. German discount chains Aldi and Lidl are capturing a larger share of U.S. grocery bills and pressuring U.S. retailers to respond.

title: A Year to Forget for Memory-Chip Makers
summary: A tough period for companies like Samsung Electronics has actually rewarded investors in the highly cyclical semiconductor industry. Better times for memory-chip makers don't necessarily spell better times for their investors.

title: Star Manager's Flagship Fund to Close After Suspension
summary: Neil Woodford built his reputation over two decades running money for Invesco but bets on unlisted and rarely traded equities soured. The flagship £2.9 billion fund of one of the U.K.'s best known money managers will be liquidated after it failed to recover from a wave of investor redemptions earlier this year, demonstrating the difficulty of fixing portfolios that become over exposed to illiquid assets.

title: The Nationals Are One Win Away From the World Series
summary: Stephen Strasburg dominated the Cardinals, giving up an unearned run over seven frames, along with 12 strikeouts in Washington's 8-1 win in Game 3. WASHINGTON-Jack Flaherty posted a 0.91 ERA in his 15 outings after the All-Star break, third-best in baseball history. Not even he could stop the Washington Nationals. Right now, nothing could.

title: Mall Short Seller Shuts Down Before the Malls He Bet Against
summary: Alder Hill Management aimed to profit by betting against debt tied to some of the country's weakest malls. The business of running malls has been reeling, but Wall Street is learning it isn't always easy to make money from their troubles.

title: Chinese Inflation Surges as Pig Prices Fly High
summary: Beijing has new impetus to buy American farm goods after consumer-price index rose 3% in September. BEIJING-Surging pork prices pushed China's consumer inflation to a near six-year high in September, complicating Beijing's effort to stimulate growth but also giving it an incentive to buy more agricultural goods from the U.S.

title: What to Watch for in Tuesday's Democratic Debate
summary: Will Elizabeth Warren be the new top target, and how will Bernie Sanders address his heart attack?. Democratic presidential hopefuls will gather in Westerville, Ohio, Tuesday for their fourth primary debate, where 12 candidates, the largest slate in modern history, are likely to see several Trump administration controversies on the agenda.

title: Warren Rises to Tie Biden in Poll of New York Democrats
summary: Bump is consistent with Warren's rise in national polls and follows a rally she held in New York City's Washington Square Park. Sen. Elizabeth Warren has gained support among New York Democrats and is now tied with former Vice President Joe Biden, a poll released Tuesday shows.

title: The New Parental Obsession: Checking Kids' Grades Online
summary: Watching a steady stream of test and homework scores is too great a temptation for some; 'There's this horrible compulsion to know'. Parents of middle- and high-schoolers are facing a new anxiety: whether or not to check their kids' grades in real time.

title: She Fined Tech Giants Billions of Dollars. Now She Wants Sharper Tools.
summary: Margrethe Vestager is pivoting away from blockbuster fines against Silicon Valley titans toward preventing market abuses in the first place. BRUSSELS-Margrethe Vestager made a name for herself as Europe's top antitrust enforcer by slapping record fines on U.S. tech companies. Now she says those fines don't work.

title: Elite M.B.A. Programs Report Steep Drop in Applications
summary: Harvard, Stanford, MIT see declines; international students find more options in Europe, Canada and Asia. Applications to some of America's most elite business schools fell at a steeper rate this year, as universities struggled to attract international students amid changes to immigration policies and political tensions between the U.S. and China.

title: Fed's James Bullard Cites Risk of Slowing Economy
summary: Overall activity may slow more than most now expect, official says. Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis President James Bullard said one of the biggest risks the economy faces is that overall activity may slow more than most now expect.

title: Where Women Fall Behind at Work: The First Step Into Management
summary: Next in Journal Reports: Leadership. The conventional narrative of the ambitious woman at work goes something like this: Woman joins the workforce with big dreams. Over the years, she advances in her career alongside male colleagues. Yet on the way to the top, she hits an invisible barrier to the highest corridors of power.

title: Sheryl Sandberg: The Gender Gap Isn't Just Unfair, It's Bad for Business
summary: Next in Journal Reports: Leadership. Women are outnumbered in corporate America from the entry level to the C-suite. It's been this way for years, and we need to get real about why. Either men are more talented, harder working, and more ambitious than women-or something unfair is happening.

title: A Lot of Women Work in Health Care. But Not at the Top. Why Is That?
summary: The leadership funnel starts contracting very early, and continues to narrow. Every year for the past four years, Harvard Medical School's three-day workshop on career advancement and leadership skills for women in health care has sold out. More than 700 women will attend next month in Boston.

title: Inside Eli Lilly's Successful Strategy to Promote More Women
summary: The company's old approach wasn't working. So it took one of its businesses processes and applied it to diversity.. Drugmakers have hits and misses when it comes to medicines, with some becoming blockbusters and others producing results so minimal they barely register in clinical trials.

title: Remedies for Early-Career Gender Gap Are Already in Companies' Hands
summary: Kevin Sneader and Lareina Yee of McKinsey say businesses can apply the same practices they are using against the glass ceiling. Commitment to gender parity at the senior level in companies has been on the rise, and we are starting to see results. The average C-suite has 24% more women than in 2015. The share of open roles going to women is rising, through either promotions or hiring.

title: Women of Color: Invisible, Excluded and Constantly 'On Guard'
summary: Research shows that women of color are the most likely to be ignored and misquoted in meetings. Invisibility and exclusion-often described as the feeling of not being heard or recognized in group settings-is a widespread problem for women of color.

title: What Democratic Candidates Are (and Aren't) Saying in Debates
summary: Here's a look at some of the top topics in the past three Democratic debates, and a few topics candidates barely have touched on. A close viewer of the Democratic primary debates so far this year might come away with an informed understanding of the presidential candidates' views on certain policy areas, such as immigration and health care.
